Topic.Title: Came in with analyst expectations: $.63 profit & $3.7 billion in revs

Message.Msg: 2 year out projections for an internet company? bah. eBay marletplace could be out of business in 2 years if social sites like Twitter and Facebook could find a way to leverage users into c2c and small b2c sales. As for Paypal, no merchant likes it, it's a necessary evil. If Visa, Mastercard and Amex were to team up in a joint initiative, Paypal would be history.

Message.Title: it's all about Ebays GROWTH initiatve starting Q2 and for the next 3 years.
Message.Msg: Q1 was okay, but ecommerce growth/mobile omnichannel GROWTH initiative. Guidance: Rev growth of 14 to 17%; paypal is GROWING focus on "delivering next generation" of services Basically repeating analyst day initiative & GROWTH expectations.

Topic.Title: Came in with analyst expectations: $.63 profit & $3.7 billion in revs

Message.Msg: Maybe if eBay would focus on business at hand instead of reaching for lofty aspirations, they might not have the expectations they do. When you lead investors to expect miracles, anything that falls short is considered downward.

Topic.Title: it's all about Ebays GROWTH initiatve starting Q2 and for the next 3 years.

Message.Msg: eBay and "next generation services" ? I almost fell off the chair laughing. Here's a company that hasn't innovated in over a decade. Same company that has programming ridden with glitches and major software issues. Well, Warren Buffett always says he won't invest in a company he hasn't done business with. Guess you have to try selling on eBay to see what a mess it is, not to mention the fees. I can't reiterate enough, never, ever invest in a company based on projections, promises or numbers. Do your due diligence, see how the company handles business and you'll pick a winner every time.

Topic.Title: e-commerce increased 19%; ebay initiative for growth start Q2 thru 2015: mobil & emerging (BRIC) markets growth

Message.Msg: As an online merchant for almost 20 years (10 years on eBay). and a brick and mortar merchant for nearly 25 years, my heart just goes pitter pat at the thought of selling to Brazil, Russia, China and India (BRIC) buyers. Three of the four countries are responsible for over 90% of the world's spam and online scams. The fourth, Brazil, has the worst postal system in the world beside Italy. Good luck. At least on eBay you can block certain countries from buying.

Message.Title: I am so sorry to my wife and kids.
Message.Msg: I bet on this losing stock and I have lost everything. Honey, I am not perfect and I made a big mistake by buying this stock. Honey, American Express, Yahoo, USB, INTC, Bank of America, AAPL ... Honey they all missed and I am sorry I got it wrong. You were right to stay on the sidelines but the DOW hit an all time high and the media said it was time to get back in. So, honey I got back in a week ago and now I have really messed up. I know things are going to get worse because these were all low estimates that these companies failed to meet ... the expectations had been lowered to the bare bone and they still missed. Honey, I can't live with these stocks ... I need to come home please let me come home and get some dry clothes... because I am all WET!

Topic.Title: The more they talk at con call more Ebay drops: bottom line do investors believe in the 20%/year growth story

Message.Msg: Been telling you this all along...... Try selling on eBay and see what merchants face. eBay IS NOT Amazon, they have no inventory of their own. no infrastructure and rely solely on third party merchants and C2C (consumer to consumer) sellers. Lowering fees across the board and getting rid of listing fees would bring eBay back to what it once was but since shareholders got involved and CEO John Donahoe's greed, eBay is a money grab doomed to failure.

Topic.Title: I am so sorry to my wife and kids.

Message.Msg: HINT.... Don't play the stock market unless you have money to burn... Rinse and repeat..

Message.Title: Buying opportunity tomorrow
Message.Msg: Late last month, eBay set aggressive three-year growth targets, based on international expansion plans and more focus on mobile commerce. The company is investing heavily in these initiatives and such spending may be behind the weaker second-quarter profit forecast, said R.J. Hottovy, an equity analyst at Morningstar. "These investments are building for the future so that should be taken positively, even if they come at the expense of short-term profits," Hottovy added, while noting that eBay's full-year 2013 forecasts remained unchanged.

Message.Title: Good chance Ebay going to $80s: Ebay's businesses PROFITABLE, growing revenue like Amazon
